fullProgramDescription: The Department of Mathematics offers a Bachelor of Science degree program that provides a broad foundation in mathematics, including pure mathematics, applied mathematics, and probability and statistics. The program is designed to provide students with a deep understanding of mathematical concepts and techniques, as well as the ability to apply them to real-world problems.
shortProgramDescription: The Mathematics B.S. program at UC Berkeley provides students with a rigorous foundation in mathematical concepts and techniques, preparing them for careers in academia, research, and industry.
classHighlights: Students are required to complete a set of core courses, including calculus (Mathematics 1A-1B), linear algebra (Mathematics 54), and differential equations (Mathematics 110 or 128A), which provide a foundation in mathematical theory and problem-solving.

The program also requires students to complete a series of upper-division courses, including real analysis (Mathematics 104 or 108), abstract algebra (Mathematics 113), and complex analysis (Mathematics 106), which provide a deeper understanding of mathematical concepts and techniques.

Students can choose from a range of electives, including courses in applied mathematics, probability and statistics, and mathematical physics, which allow them to tailor their program to their interests and career goals.

The department also offers a range of specialized courses, including mathematics education and history of mathematics, which provide students with a broader understanding of the field and its applications.
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a deep understanding of mathematical concepts and techniques, including calculus, linear algebra, and differential equations.
Apply mathematical concepts and techniques to real-world problems, including problems in physics, engineering, and economics.
Communicate mathematical ideas and results effectively, both orally and in writing.
Analyze and interpret mathematical data, including data from experiments and simulations.
Understand the historical and cultural context of mathematics, including the contributions of mathematicians from diverse backgrounds.
additionalInformation: Students must complete the university's general education requirements and maintain a minimum GPA of 2.0. The department also offers a range of advising and support services to help students navigate the program and achieve their goals.
